facts.text: Plaintiffs-appellants are consumers of electricity in Godhra area.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs appellants who are companysumers of electricity in the Godhra area sued the respondent-company on behalf of all the companysumers in that area

facts.text: Suits are representative suits on behalf of all consumers in Godhra area.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs appellants who are companysumers of electricity in the Godhra area sued the respondent-company on behalf of all the companysumers in that area seeking to restrain

facts.text: On November 19, 1922, Government of Bombay granted licence under Indian Electricity Act, 1910 to Lady Sulochna Chinubhai Co. to generate and supply electricity in Godhra area.

anchor.surface_text: On November 19, 1922, the then Government of Bombay granted a licence under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 to a companycern called Lady Sulochna Chinubhai Co. authorising it to generate and supply electricity to the companysumers in Godhra area.

facts.text: Respondent is successor of the licensee Lady Sulochna Chinubhai Co.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 10 of the licence prescribed the maximum charges that the licensee companyld levy for the power supplied. The respondent is the successor of the said licensee.

facts.text: Clause 10 of the licence prescribed maximum charges licensee could levy.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 10 of the licence prescribed the maximum charges that the licensee companyld levy for the power supplied.

facts.text: Rating committee constituted under s.57(2) of Supply Act on January 19, 1950 at request of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: After the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 ... came into force, a rating companymittee was companystituted under s. 57 2 of the Supply Act at the request of the respondent on January 19, 1950.

facts.text: Government fixed charges effective February 1, 1952 based on rating committee recommendation: lights and fans 0-7-9 pies per unit min Rs. 3/- per month per installation; motive power 4 annas per unit min Rs. 4-8-0 per month per installation.

anchor.surface_text: On the recommendation of that companymittee, the Government fixed with effect from February 1, 1952, the following charges for the power supplied 0-7-9 pies per unit for the electricity supplied for lights and fans with a minimum of Rs. 3/- per month per installation and for motive power at 4 annas per unit with a minimum of Rs. 4-8-0 per month per installation.

facts.text: Electricity Supply Act, 1948 amended in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Supply Act was amended in 1956.

facts.text: Respondent increased charges for motive power from January 1, 1963 to 35 NP per unit with minimum Rs. 7/- per month per installation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent increas the charges for motive power from January 1, 1963 to 35 NP. per unit with a minimum of Rs. 7/- per month for every installation.

facts.text: On June 22, 1963, respondent increased rates for lights and fans effective July 1, 1963 to 70 NP per unit with minimum Rs. 5/- per month per installation.

anchor.surface_text: On June 22., 1963, the rates for light and fans were increased with effect from July 1, 1963 to 70 NP. per unit with a minimum of Rs. 51- per month for every installation.

facts.text: Appellants contend respondent not competent to enhance charges without rating committee consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants is that the respondent wag number companypetent to enhance the charges, in question without the matter having been companysidered by a rating companymittee.

facts.text: Suits to restrain respondent from levying increased charges dismissed by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Their suits to restrain the respondent from levying the proposed increased charges were decreased by the trial companyrt.

facts.text: Trial court decrees affirmed by first appellate court and single judge of Gujarat High Court in second appeals.

anchor.surface_text: Those decrees were affirmed by the first appellate companyrt as well as by a single judge of the Gujarat High Court in second appeals

facts.text: Gujarat High Court appellate bench reversed decrees and dismissed suits, holding respondent has unilateral right under Supply Act as amended in 1956 subject to VI Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: but the appellate bench of the Gujarat High Court reversed those decrees and dismissed the suits holding that under the Supply Act as amended in 1956 the respondent has a unilateral right to enhance the charges subject to the companyditions prescribed in the VI Schedule to that Act.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 15 of 1969 relates to enhancement of charges for lights and fans.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 16 of 1969 relates to enhancement of charges for motive power.

anchor.surface_text: and Civil Appeal No. 16 of 1969 relates to the enhancement of charges for the motive power.

issues.text: whether under the provisions of the Supply Act as amended in 1956, the respondent was competent to unilaterally enhance the charges

anchor.surface_text: It is as against those decisions these appeals have been brought. Civil Appeal No. 15 of 1969 relates to the enhancement of charges for electricity power for lights and fans and Civil Appeal No. 16 of 1969 relates to the enhancement of charges for the motive power. The only question that arises-for decision in these appeals is whether under the provisions of the Supply Act as amended in 1956, the respondent was companypetent to unilaterally enhance the charges.

issues.text: whether the appellants have a vested right to be governed by the charges fixed in 1952 until the same is revised by the Government on the basis of the recommendation of a rating committee

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute as regards the charges fixed by the Government with effect from February 1, 1952, under s. 57 2  c  of the Supply Act on the basis of the recommendation made by the rating companymittee. The appellants admit their liability to pay enhanced charges that may be fixed by the Government on the basis of any recommendation by a freshly, appointed rating companymittee. They merely challenge the respondents right to unilaterally enhance the charges. According to the appellants they have a vested right to be governed by the charges fixed in 1952 until the same is revised by the Government

issues.text: whether the amendments made in 1956 affect the charges fixed in 1952 and whether they continue to rule till altered by the Government in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellants they have a vested right to be governed by the charges fixed in 1952 until the same is revised by the Government on the basis of the recommendation of a rating companymittee. It was urged on their behalf that the amendments made in 1956 do number affect the charges fixed in 1952 and they companytinue to rule till altered by the Government in accordance with law.

issues.text: whether the charges fixed by the Government under old s.57(2)(c) can only be modified by a new rating committee or can be unilaterally altered by licensee after expiry of specified period under amended Sch. VI

anchor.surface_text: From an examination of these- provisions it would be seen that under the Supply Act prior to its amendment in 1956, the charges fixed by the Govt. under s 57 2  c  remained in force unless reduced by the licensee in the meantime till the same were altered by a subsequent order made by the Govt. after getting a fresh recommendation from the rating companymittee but under the law as it number stands the rate fixed by the Government under s. 57  A  1  d  would be in operation only for such period number exceeding three years as the State Govt. may specify in the order. Thereafter it can be enhanced by the licensee in accordance with the provisions companytained in Sch. VI.

arguments.claim: Amendments to Supply Act in 1956 substantially altered scheme allowing licensee to unilaterally alter charges fixed by Government subject to s.57A and Sch VI

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on its behalf that the amendments made to the Supply Act in 1956 have substantially altered the scheme as regards levying charges it is now open to a licensee to alter the charges fixed by the Government unilaterally subject to the conditions prescribed in s. 57 A and in Sch. VI of the Supply Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d into the licence the provisions of Sch. VI and strike out therefrom such terms as are inconsistent with those provisions and thereafter give effect

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmed by examination of pre and post amendment provisions

arguments.claim: Even according to appellants, licensee can unilaterally alter charges after expiry of period in Government order per cl e of s57A(1)

anchor.surface_text: We may mention at this stage that even according to the appellants the charges that may be fixed by the Government not on the basis of the recommendation of a rating committee can be unilaterally altered by the licensee after the period fixed in the Government order in accordance with cl. e of S. 57 A 1 , expires.

arguments.claim: Under pre-1956 law, charges under s57(2)(c) in force till altered by new govt order on rating committee; post-amendment, govt-fixed rates under s57A(1)(d) only for specified period not exceeding 3 years, thereafter licensee enhances per Sch VI
Present s.57A(1)(e) governs only charges fixed under s.57A(1)(d), no impact on old s.57(2)(c) orders which can only be modified by govt after rating committee report
arguments.court_reasoning: s57 deems Sch VI incorporated into all licences including pre-commencement, overriding inconsistent priors

arguments.claim: Consumers have vested right in 1952 charges not taken away by amending Act; amendment not retrospective, no inconsistency with prior provisions, s6 General Clauses Act applies so 1952 charges continue

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chagla, learned Counsel for the appellants contended that the consumers who get power from the respondent have a vested right in the charges fixed in 1952 and that vested right cannot be considered to have been taken away by the provisions of the Amending Act. He argued that the provisions of the Amending Act are not retrospective in character nor is there any inconsistency between those provisions and the present provisions as the two operate on different fields hence in view of s. 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, we must hold that the charges fixed by the Government in 1952 continue to be in operation.

arguments.court_reasoning: s6 GCA not applicable as not mere repeal; no vested rights affected, only procedure; cites Mohar Singh distinction

arguments.claim: Rights and liabilities now exclusively regulated by current Supply Act; original licence terms or pre-1956 terms irrelevant; must look to licence as modified by current provisions; no vested rights, only procedure for modifying 1952 charges

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it was contended by the learned Counsel for the respondent that the rights and liabilities of the respondents at present are exclusively regulated by the provisions of the Supply Act as it stands now the terms of licences as they originally stood or as they stood on the coming into force of the Supply Act in 1948 are of no consequence nor they cannot be looked into for finding out the rights or duties of the licensee as at present for that purpose we must look into those terms as modified by the provisions of the Supply Act as it is now. It was also urged on its behalf that there is no question of vested rights in these cases herein we are only concerned with the procedure to be adopted in modifying the charges fixed in 1952.

arguments.court_reasoning: s57 incorporates Sch VI overriding inconsistent prior terms per explicit language

arguments.claim: s6 GCA applies only to repeal simpliciter or re-enactment; when repeal followed by fresh legislation, check if new Act destroys old rights; here no such intention
No vested right affected as controversy is only about procedure to alter charges, which must be per law in force at time of alteration
s57 deems Sch VI incorporated into pre-existing licences from next year of account; inconsistent prior provisions void
No reason prior licensees disadvantaged vs new; no reason consumers of prior licensees better off; amendment to meet changing economics with machinery for refund excess
Licensee has unilateral right under para 1 Sch VI to adjust rates so clear profit not exceed reasonable return
In Amalgamated Electricity, s57 and Sch VI override licence maximum charges; licensee right unilateral under para 1 Sch VI

holdings.text: there is no dispute that the respondent was within its rights in enhancing the charges as admittedly it has followed the procedure prescribed by law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Licence terms as modified by s.57 and Sch.VI permit unilateral adjustment after notice; respondent complied; prior terms irrelevant.

holdings.text: But in the cases before us there is no question of affecting any vested right. There is no dispute that the charges fixed can be altered. The controversy relates to the procedure to be adopted in altering them. That controversy does not touch any vested right.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute is purely procedural for charge alteration, governed by law in force; no accrued substantive right affected.

holdings.text: The procedure in question must necessarily be regulated by the law in force at the time of the alteration of the charges.

anchor.surface_text: The procedure in question must necessarily be regulated by the law in force at the time of the alteration of the charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge alteration procedure follows current statute, not frozen at 1952; amendment changes scheme substantially.

holdings.text: in view of s. 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, we must hold that the charges fixed by the Government in 1952 continue to be in operation.

anchor.surface_text: hence in view of s. 6 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, we must hold that the charges fixed by the Government in 1952 continue to be in operation. In this connection he relied on certain observations

holdings.reasoning_summary: s6 GCA inapplicable as amendment not repeal simpliciter; new provisions show intent to change procedure; cites Mohar Singh.

holdings.text: Section 57 of the Supply Act as it stands now lays down that the provisions of Sch. VI shall be deemed to be incorporated in the licence of every licensee not being a local authority, in the case of a licence granted before the commencement of the Act from the date of the commencement of the licensees next succeeding year of account.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory deeming applies to pre-Act licences; overrides priors per s57(1).

holdings.text: If any of the earlier provisions in the licence either as they stood when the licence was originally granted or as they stood modified as per the provisions of the Supply Act prior to its amendment in 1956 are inconsistent ,with the provisions of Sch. VI or s. 57 A  as they are now they must be held to be void and of no effect.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s57 voids inconsistent prior licence terms, 1910 Act, agreements; Clause 10 and 1952 order overridden.

holdings.text: From an examination of these provisions it would be seen that under the Supply Act prior to its amendment in 1956, the charges fixed by the Govt. under s 57 2 c remained in force unless reduced by the licensee in the meantime till the same were altered by a subsequent order made by the Govt. after getting a fresh recommendation from the rating committee but under the law as it now stands the rate fixed by the Government under s. 57 A 1 d would be in operation only for such period not exceeding three years as the State Govt. may specify in the order. Thereafter it can be enhanced by the licensee in accordance with the provisions contained in Sch. VI.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-1956: govt-fixed till new committee; post: limited to 3 yrs max, then licensee per Sch VI.

holdings.text: This Court held that the maximum stipulated in the licence no longer governed the right of the licensee to enhance the charges his rights were exclusively governed by the provisions contained in paragraph 1 of Sch. VI of the Supply Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves and applies Amalgamated precedent: Sch VI para 1 exclusively governs enhancement right over licence max.
